reviews.review_text: This is such a refreshing and addicting game.   The turn-based combat in this game is unique and it requires teamwork and smart thinking.  - The Characters are unique and have their own skills, playstyles and are balanced.  - The free to play model is fair and good: You can play VS. Bots And PVP, Ranked and custom games are locked for the full version, but you can still have plenty of fun with the free version ( I personally still play the free version, and love it.)  Now one of the main issues people has, is that you can't purchase skins, if you don't have the full game. And i do somewhat agree with that, it feels restricting. But what they fail to realize is that if you just play the game and level up a certain character, you gain ''loot crates'' for that character. And in those loot crates you can get skins, even in the free version. I have personally already optained a couple, so it is possible.

Please ignore the bad reviews that specif complain about paying for the heroes. This is a PAID GAME, the Free to play mode is more like a demo with limited herores which you can play online with only five. (Pretty much like LoL, Paladins, etc)  It is not fair to bash bad a product because you have to pay for it, it is insane.   You pay 26 dollar, 56 reais, and you get al heroes, are able to do ranked matches and open as many loot boxes as u want.  Very smart and strategic game, very like XCOM.  They already update with a new hero very quick, they have a couple of skins for each hero and only a few maps.  The game has a great potential and the heroes are unique, has some moba feel to it too. Just try it the free version, if you like it, buy it.  It is a great game and well supported.

This game is awesome! It is essentially like XCOM, just online and with/against other players. Round-based combat with different phases, characters and abilities. I am always skeptical when I hear the word 'Trion' but this time they have outdone themselves.  People are annoyed at the free model, and it could certainly be better - you get a few freelancers in a rotation and have a timer on lootboxes   *EDIT: This restriction is now gone. They really listen to feedback!*.   But otherwise, even the free version is awesome, though I highly recommend buying the game - it is well worth the price. The free version is great for trying it out though.   It is a highly unique concept and just works insanely well, what with there being support characters that heal and shield others, Frontlines and damage dealers, and every character being distinctively different. Great fun! Graphics are fitting and the characters are charming. Definitely recommended!  Edit: What I find sad is that I find many people here on a crusade against the developer, downvoting every positive review. While it is true that the dev has ♥♥♥♥ed up games in the past before, I would still like you to give this game a chance - it may very well be a fresh start for Trion and even though I have been burned on their games before in the past, I have a feeling this one will be different, just judging from playing it myself. Look at the game, not the developer - just have fun, because that is what video games are for. Plus, the free demo mode shows you all you need to know about the game. If you won't like it, then there is no investment lost.

It's a really great game, lots of fun and suprisingly fast paced despite being turn based. I really love it, people are downvoting because they feel cheated because it's not free. Whether that's a legitimate concern I don't know, I bought it and I really enjoy it.

So far, I really like this game, even with just the free rotation characters. I don't usually like turn based combat, but it's a different case when it requires quick thinking. Atlas Reactor, to me, is basically a combination of strategy, quick thinking skills, and game knowledge. It combines turn based combat, combat roles, strategy and competitive play. With more maps, characters, playerbase, community, and content in general, this game could easily be just as popular as other MOBAs. As for the graphics, Atlas Reactor is simple (but nicely stylised), straightforward and mostly effective. The only bones I have to pick are the vagueness of the tutorial (really need an advanced one with introduction to roles, explaining little things like time banks, stealth blocks, advanced pings etc), some tooltips, and there are still some graphical glitches (clipping taunts and crazy ragdolls which make me XD). It's f2p, so I highly recommend at least giving it a go.

This is going to be an honest review of this game.  If anything, going into this game I was already predjudiced after the devolopers of Trion's other game, Trove, screwed it up for the most part. I did not even expect this to be a game I liked, as this game is very similar to XCOM, only multiplayer. I had never played XCOM.   So here's the pro's of this game: +Unskippable but informative tutorial +Decent graphics reminiscent of Boderlands +Memorable characters with unique abilities +Everything happens in the game can be understood, there are no secrets to abilities +An original story with some decent lore that connects all the characters +Balanced and well designed maps  ~  And the cons: -Turns are conducted in a short amount of time, and while this adapted to with time, it is hard to start with -Turns in blast phase seem to happen in random order, which can be confusing -Free version only gives a rotation of 5 characters (see 'Message to negative reviews' for more on this) -Some characters are just not as useful as others -Can be hard to learn all of the abilites of every character  So now thta you have the pros and cons; My thoughts on the game:  It's fun. It is a satisfying game to play, even though it is of a genre that I'm noth that interested in. The game is very well optimized, with only a few crashes here and there. Honestyly this game has a lot of depth and would recommend it to anyone mainly interested in tactics based games.  Message to negative reviews:  I see most negative reviews talk about how they don't get the full game for free. Mainly, most people are mad that they can't buy the characters instead of the full game. This is probably due to people being used to LOL so thats what they've come to expect. I don't blame them, but its not reason to give the entire game a negative review. I mean, people should specialize in many characters anyway. To the people who wanted the entire game to be free, I don't get why you got that impression, as it says nowhere on the game's website, and the free beta was an 'open beta', meaning open to anyone. It's stupid to negatively review a game when it was never said that the full game would be free. If anything, everyone should be happy that they get some access for free.

I'm not much of a gamer compared to most people who would consider themselves gamers. When I play, I play mostly MMOs and light games that don't require a whole lot of time investment. Strategy games? They take a long time, and when you lose, you lose everything you built up for the last x hours. Turn-based sounds slow and boring. Battle arenas seem to be full of 12yo's expanding their vocabularies. And then, somehow, Atlas Reactor happened and got me hooked.  There are a bunch of reviews that describe how the game works, so I'll just share my impressions of the game. The gameplay feels very polished, the characters have a lot of personality, and each match is different from the last, which is probably my favorite part. It's also cool that each match takes only about 20 minutes - if I don't have much time due to work and life in general, I can still get a game or two in and have a ton of fun. I'm actually glad that I usually can't play for hours at a time, because it really is addicting. :P

Love this game. It is free to play. Not the free-to-play you're thinking though. I played about 25 hours free, then decided Trion earned my money. If it looks interesting, try it out for free. The game is tactically deep and knowing all the Freelancers moves helps planning your turn out. I was fully prepared to stay 'free to play' but think enough of this game to pay $30 for it. It's sad that Free-to-Play hurts a game. I think in this case, the developer just wanted to give people an option to try it out without putting any money down, and they are getting blasted for it. This game might review better if they hadn't done the free model, but I probably wouldn't have given it a shot. Download this and play it. Do what you want with your $30 afterward.

It's a thinking game. It's team base ( 4x4) as free lancers (guns for hire ) where you try to take out the other team using team tactics in a grid base, turn base tactics game. Choose between frontline, support or firepower freelancers to help your team. Each freelancer and their respective type has diffrent skills, abilities and playing styles to help bring about the edge to win. Work together with your team to either capture and turn in a breifcase in extraction with 10 points/kills or first to 5 kills in a straight fight. Each freelancer is full of character and theme base that really makes it fun. Taunts are cut scenes that you can earn for each freelancer along with skins and banners for your profile by playing and leveling them up. Taunts are used in game to well, taunt or for a good laugh during a game. I rather enjoyed them. Leveling up the freelancer and your profile to earn banner backgrounds, pictures and emoticons for some custimizable fun. Colors and graphics and all that to represent you on your profile. Facing pvp or AI is up to you and completing missions and daily's is a good way to get modular points and iso's to unlock more freelancers/profile banner goods. Mods are fun little perks you can equip your free lancers with to help damage or gain sheilds depending on how you want to play. They help out or piggyback specific moves your freelancer does. Catalysts help too. These are used to perform specific actions during a fight. Games are back and forth turns with 3 steps per team turn. PREP, in witch sheilds or healing or throwing of traps around happens along with dashing in witch freelancers do a quick dash if they choose to, BURST, the freelancers fire guns or swing swords and whatever at each other, MOVE, then freelancers run or move or fly whatever where they wanted to if able or can ...Find the right combination of mods and catalysts on your freelancer to really help out your team. Dailies are fun challanges, but it really comes with the season missions. A story line of this crazy game of corperations and espionage, world dominations and freelancers trying to earn money is available. Read the story and complete the season missions for really good rewards. Complete more missions to advance the story line. A good read that seems to really build upon the aggresive negotiation of bussiness and science in the future. The music is super catchy and admittingly I bob my head to the theme/ main page song while waiting for games. Give it a try, honestly with such fun characters and a game that really brings this genre together with flashy modern themes and music. Learn the game with a quick prologue missions tuturial and play bots. LEARN the game before jumping into the deep. Alot of good guesswork and thinking stratagy wise is actually needed here! Limited maps and freelancers is the only bummer so far, they just need to grow and expand and people will start noticing...

However there is one thing about the game that does hurt it in my book, that being its pay to play influence. Although listed under the f2p category, to get the full experience you need to shell out at least 30 dollars or more. There is no currency that you can earn through play meaning there is no system of purchasing individual characters to unlock permanently like in other MOBAS. Which means you have to use the free rotation every time to play as characters if you dont want to pay. And honestly I wouldnt mind paying if it were more f2p friendly because, as previously stated, this game is generally a good time. Definetly try it but if they don't make it more f2p friendly I may have to sadly let this game go.

So, to begin with I am going to say that if you hate Trion and would not TRY the game because of that, you should probably throw that out of the window.  Atlas reactor is a 4v4 simultaneous turn based battle arena. Players each get to control a single character and are required to work with their team to have 5 takedowns (kills) or have the most takedowns by 20 turns.  Its a fresh sort of game which is hard to come by nowadays. It allows for players who are not very technical, but who are very smart and can outthink their opponents to shine. It has a very large learning skill ceiling, as moving a single unit differently could change the outcome of the game.  It has a free to play COMPONENT (This is not a free to play game) that allows for people to trial the game, in which I seriously recommend doing so. It may take you 10 games before you get the hang of it, but it is definitely worth it.

Atlas Reactor is a fun little game that takes some elements from turn based squad games (like XCom) and mixes them with other elements from MOBAs. You've got twenty seconds to enter your move for the turn, and then the action goes off.  It leads to fun mind-games where you're trying to decide whether your opponent thinks you will dash to that location over there, so they might attack that location instead of where you actually are, so you decide that since your correct course of action is so obvious, that you'll instead stay put and... then you find out they called your bluff.  Never go in against a Sicilian when death is on the line!  The character bios are awesome as well, especially Oz, the recalled toy-bot (for displaying freewill and weapon-grade lasers) and Quark, the homicidal... thingie... that just wants to tickle your neurons.  I recommend this game for anyone old enough to have played games like Jagged Alliance and who doesn't want to wade into the toxic morass of other MOBA communities.  Edit: Regarding the 'free to try' nature of the game - they let you try the game out for free. It's not intended to be played forever like an actual free to play title. If you like the game, buy the damn package. If you don't, then stop complaining that they give you a random selection of four characters (that rotate) to play around with in the meantime.

This game is a LOT of fun.  It's unique. It's 4v4 pvp simultaneous turn tactics. Broken down, everyone decides what they want to do (one action then one move) ahead of time and locks it in. Then the phases go off in order and you get to see what everyone locked in! games go a LOT faster then other turn or tactics games with the 20 second limit on turns and 8 people all taking their turns at the same time.  This alone would be neat and novel, but what makes the game great is how tactical and deep and balanced the game is. One of those 'simple idea, complex strategy' type deals. There are already high level tournaments where top teams are repeatedly winning, showing player skill cap is a HUGE factor.  I've been playing atlas reactor a LOT the past few months, and even more in the future to come.

Atlas Reactor is a child of Overwatch and Xcom. The combat is Xcom style, where you instead control only one character. Your abilities and dealt damage built up to your ultimate bar. The game has multiple heroes, or 'Freelancers' in this case, and they all have different play styles and abilities to be aware of.  Matches are pretty well phased and the balancing is great. Matches also don't take too long to finish.  The game is basically pay to play, but you can also play a trial version with free heroes, but you cannot unlock heroes by playing.  Overall a really fun and addicting game.

A very interesting system, to be sure. I've had a lot of fun with the 'free to play' version, but more on that in a minute.  The characters are all endearing and pretty fun to play once you get a grasp of the core mechanics, which are a fresh take on... MOBAs? Not really. There are no ingame upgrades, and most building is done pre-game. There are some really interesting concepts going on here, and I'm really waiting to see what comes of it when the cast expands a bit.  Which brings me to my main gripes. The cast is very small for this sort of game, weighing in at 5 supports, 5 tanks, and 9 DPS as of the time of this writing. If you are the type that likes switching characters and roles frequently, your interest will wane much faster than with other team based games. The core mechanics may carry the game for you, however.   Lastly, this game isn't actually a FTP. The FTP model works more as a demo, really. This is fine as far as I'm concerned, but it should really be listed in the store as such.   Additional plus, I'm running this on a potato and aside from the occasional framerate chug, I'm running it pretty fine.

Ever since I came across Atlas Reactor, I was worried that it might fall into the 'It takes too much time' category. Since, in my opinion, games that grant instant gratification rather than requiring lots of effort to reach satisfaction are blossoming nowadays, Atlas Reactor had fallen in the latter category for me on first sight and had me questioning wether I should invest in getting it or not. The concept was great and fresh, game mechanics looked like they work fantastic, and since it's 4Vs4 type of game, you could have a much tighter space too cooperate with teammates. Once I learned that Atlas Reactor offered a 'Demo Version', and I call it that because people who read Free to Play get super salty when everything isn't free, I was delighted and decided to give it a go. I was simply amazed at the freshness of game concept Atlas Reactor had to offer. Matches were MUCH shorter than I had expected and it was more adrenaline inducing that the majority of my Dota2 games, all within 20 seconds of deciding what to do. After reaching about lvl 8 with my account, I reached a point where I thought to myself, I should definitely buy and support this game. And it was one of the best game purchasing decisions I ever made. I hope this game goes far. I truly do.

i faking love this game.  Played it prior to steam 'release' already and it's just so much fun outplayin' ya enemies.  Goal is to score 5 kills or the 'golden kill', if both teams are tied after 20 rounds. First you start with a planning phase and then both teams turns are played in four phases. First a preperation phase, where buffs are applied. Then a dash phase, where ...well, you guessed it, dashes of all kinds are used. Then comes the blast phase, in which all attacks are used. Last comes the movement phase, where all players run and reposition.  This forces you to think ahead. 'I could kill him, but does he have a dash? Where could he dash to, can i shoot the approximate position and kill him after he dashed?'  You should master those thoughts. And when, some day, you play against your friends and stomp them and they insult you, you can be like: 'I am five steps ahead of you. Scrubs.' <3

First, there was a bit a confusion about whether it's F2P game. Not really, no. You can try it for free, but there are features and characters locked out for you. You must buy the game to fully unlock all features. Once you bought it though, you have it forever. I find this much better than those 'free to play' games out there, that actually ask more and more money from you with each new thing. Taunts and purely cosmetic stuff is unlocked by playing, which is part of the fun, and it actually is happening at a nicely fast pace.  The game is really great. I recommend snatching it at a 33% discount like me, but for me it's well worth the full price. Heck, I even bought the ultimate edition because I enjoy it this much. Best served with friends btw.  The turn based system is simple yet well made, first comes the decision phase, you decide what you gonna do, then everything happens simultaneously. This brings a lot of funny and/or wtf-moments, and every match unfolds differently. Unlike MOBAs, there is no snowballing, no lined up way to play, no laning here. You need to use brain a bit, presume enemy actions and play mind games with them. It's not overly hard though, no worry.  Pros: Interesting turn-based gameplay. Varied and fun characters. 'Buy once, play forever' type of obtaining the game. Great attentive devs.  Cons: Menus look slightly obsolete at this point. Occasional bugs.  The game is at the beggining of its path, updates come often and bring new characters and maps, it can grow a a lot from this point, and it will. Thumbs up, I am looking forward for new characters and stuff.

Dispite being listed as a F2P it really isn't.   If you guys ever played any F2P MOBA you know about those weekly hero rotations where a limited number of heroes is made available. This is the case with this games 'Free' mode. You never get to really own a hero, you are limited to those random hero rotations.   Other than that it is a simple arena brawler with a turn based twist.  The gameplay itself is ok, you essentially try to predict enemy movement and catch them offguard since gameplay happens simulataniously. This means everyone plans their turns and then executes them at the same time. You have a rather small amount of heroes with rather boring abilities compared to lets say LoL or DotA 2.  Ultimately the maps are boring aswell, there seems to be a steampunk/scifi theme going on.  There is an ingame tutorial, play vs AI , casual pvp and ranked pvp mode. Ranked pvp is behind the paygate.  The graphics are ok and it runs decent on my 3 year old PC. They went for a cell shading style similar to borderlands on their characters and a very boring generic 3D style for the environment.  Overall a good idea but a boring execution.

Atlas Reactor, a fun game about playing a Freelancer in a fast paced turn based strategy game that is oh so slightly reminicent of Xcom. The game takes place on a 20 second turn timer were you set up your move and see what your team mates are doing. Then those moves you set up happen in phases. The phases are as follows. The Prep phase is where healing, support, and trap like actions occur, This makes it so you can keep up yourself or your team before the figurative (sometimes literal) bombs drop. Next up comes the dash phase, were you get to do a quick, most of the time short move. Almost every freelancer has a dash abillity they can use, They can do damage, stealth you after a short teleport, stop the enemy from moving later, and save you from a bad situation such as an entire team surrounding you. The next runner up is the Blast phase. This stage, unsurprisingly, has a lot of blasting. Almost all abillities in this phase go in a sort of order that you more or less learn by playing. It's made so that the abilities that deal straight up damage go before the abilities that move people around go. While this keeps a lot of cockblocking from happening, poor team coordination still ♥♥♥♥s things up. Finally there is the move phase, where you move normaly if you're still alive after all of that. You keep doing this until one team gets 5 kills, or has more kills than the other at 20 turns. There are 3 or 4 maps that have enough variety in how you play on them for you to notice. That's about it on the gameplay side, time to get to the big issue. I haven't read much into why Atlas is like this, but its a free to play, but as Trion is involved with it, there's something off. The one thing that could ruin this wonderful, hero based game, is by restricting heroes. You see, Im not sure why this is, and it might just be a slow adjustment out of EARLY early access, but you have to pay to be able to have access to all Freelancers at all times. It tries to make up for this with a free rotation change that happens every two weeks, and is unique for each play, but it doesn't work to well when you want to play who your comfortable with after a bad losing streak. It also tries to make up for it by giving you access to lootcrates in the free version, and you get to open one every two days or so. This lets you have a wide variety of cosmetics that you would have to pay several bucks for in any other game. Once again, you can't own freelancers, so it's like getting nothing but that loot you didn't want when you pay for those keys or chests in other games like TF2 and Smite. So, if they get rid of this and make it a proper F2P with a sort of Ultimate Character Pack like the other good games, then I would totally be 100 percent reccomending this game.  So, in short, the Gameplay is wonderful, most fun I've had with friends since I started playing smite about 3 years ago. But, at the moment, gameplay is all it's got going for it. If it wants to be popular in any way, shape, or form, then it's gonna have to fix how it's doing it's free to play.  ___________________________________________________________________ The Real ♥♥♥♥  Alright, it's Trion. They've officially been working a lot on it and I see that they've been keeping with the fact that It's not free to play unless your fine with just Free rotation, So yea. Im done, fun gameplay cant be all that holds up a free to play game.
